Award.AwardTitle: Partial Support of the Committee on Radio Frequencies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Academy of Sciences' Committee on Radio Frequencies is comprised of prominent scientists and engineers who provide studies and advice to the Academy on issues involving scientific uses of the radio spectrum. Such uses often involve techniques and applications that are outside the realm of traditional radio spectrum applications. The Committee provides advice and guidance to the FCC (through filings in appropriate FCC proceedings) and other regulatory bodies toward the adoption of spectrum rules and policies needed to protect sensitive science applications that make use of the radio spectrum, particularly in the fields of radio astronomy, meteorology, remote sensing, oceanography, and some other sciences. Because of the multi-disciplinary aspect of the Committee's goals, it is supported by both the National Science Foundation and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The full Committee, comprised of 15 members, meets regularly, twice a year, and between meetings it works on crafting comments and other written documents in response to various regulatory proceedings. Some recent publications are: Handbook of Frequency Allocations and Spectrum Protection for Scientific Uses (National Academies Press, 2015). The Committee also sends representatives to appropriate meetings of scientific (e.g., the International Union of Radio Scientists) and policy-setting bodies (e.g., the International Telecommunication Union) to help publicize their positions.

Intellectual merit: This proposal is not for scientific research, but it constitutes fundamental support for protecting the infrastructure that allows carrying out such research. There is a need to protect the scientific uses of the spectrum, particularly in view of the ever-increasing number of commercial uses, particularly wireless applications.

Broader impact: 1) Without CORF as a watchdog, much of radio astronomy and remote sensing might become impossible within just a few years, as the radio spectrum becomes more and more crowded. 2) CORF's outreach activities to specialized audiences, such as the FCC and to the general public, about the need of scientists to have access to portions of the radio spectrum and 3) CORF's attempt to involve younger scientists in engineering and spectrum management issues are also deemed to contribute to the broader impact of the committee.

The Committee maintains a website, where CORF filings are available, along with presentations at the meetings and other useful information.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Committee on Radio Frequencies (CORF) brings the prestige of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (the "National Academies") to the protection of the radio frequency interests of radio astronomers, remote-sensing researchers, and other scientific users of the radio spectrum. CORF's chief task is to coordinate the needs for radio-frequency allocations and protection from radio-frequency interference for U.S. scientific research. CORF brings together representatives from such fields as space science, radio astronomy, atmospheric science, oceanography, and remote sensing. As an activity of the National Academies, CORF provides independent, external advice that must pass National Academies review before it is delivered to the federal government. The frequency needs of the scientific and related engineering communities have become greater as radio research techniques and instruments have become more sophisticated and sensitive. For many researchers, CORF serves as a channel for presenting their needs to federal regulatory agencies and for protecting their frequencies from encroachment by commercial competition. CORF represents the interests of both nongovernmental scientists and federally supported scientists.

Over the three-year period of this award, CORF filed 14 comments on public proceedings before the Federal Communications Commission regarding allocation and assignment of radio frequencies and other regulatory matters especially for radio astronomy and Earth remote sensing. All CORF filings can be found on the committee's website: https://www.nationalacademies.org/our-work/committee-on-radio-frequencies

CORF holds monthly teleconferences to stay up to date and aware of developments it may need to pay attention to, and holds extra teleconferences when warranted to discuss details. The committee also meets each spring and fall. The spring meetings are held at the Keck Center of the National Academies in Washington, D.C., and typically bring together CORF members, representatives from NSF, NASA, NOAA, the FCC, and the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA). This provides an important opportunity for frequency managers from various agencies to meet with each other and with members of the radio science community. The NSF and NASA spectrum managers work with CORF both as program managers for the agencies and as agency representatives on the Interdepartmental Radio Advisory Committee (IRAC). In 2020, the spring meeting was held virtually in May 2020. The fall meetings are designed for the committee to work on dissemination materials and outreach opportunities, and discuss matters of importance in alignment with its goals. Fall meetings for this award period were held in October 2018 in Woods Hole, MA, and September 2019 in Socorro, NM, where the committee and guests from the meeting could tour the Very Large Array. The fall 2020 meeting was held virtually, and that provided an opportunity for the committee to hear from representatives of international organizations and engage with many members of NASA's Earth Sciences Division.

In addition to the FCC Comments described above, CORF maintains regular contact with many international and domestic entities engaged in radio frequency spectrum management and use.  CORF also engages with and provides expertise in radio frequency spectrum management issues to other National Academies' Boards, such as the Space Studies Board, the Computer Science and Telecommunications Board, the Polar Research Board, the Board on International Scientific Organizations, and the Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate. CORF also works with the American Astronomical Society in informing the radio astronomy community about spectrum management matters, and soliciting their input as issues arise. CORF also has contact with the IEEE's GRSS-FARS Committee.

CORF committee members gain an insight into how radio frequency allocations, policy, and regulations are made and how to communicate issues involving radio spectrum management with their colleagues. CORF serves a valuable role in educating the scientific community, the government, and the public concerning the impact of radio frequency interference on scientific uses of the spectrum. Through participating in CORF meetings and activities, committee members acquire significant knowledge of radio spectrum management and regulatory issues in other fields, as well as their own.  They also are able to bring that experience back to their institutions and community. Staff have heard from current and past CORF members, as well as general members of the community, that the committee plays a vital role in training and sensitizing the science communities that use radio frequencies to spectrum management and sharing issues.

The CORF Handbook (2nd Ed.), "Active Sensing" and the World Radiocommunication Conference 2019 (WRC-2019) "Views" reports have been downloaded (for free) by thousands of people and distributed for free to hundreds of individuals since their publications. CORF reports over the past decade have been downloaded over 13,000 times. In 2019, a new brochure was created in order to showcase CORF?s mission and purpose in an easily-accessible way. The brochure can be downloaded directly as a PDF from the CORF website, linked above.
